title: The importance of auditory-visual interaction in the construction of tranquil spaces.
abstract:
noIn a world of sensory overload, it is becoming increasingly important to provide environments that\ud
enable us to recover our sense of well being. Such restorative (`tranquil¿) environments need to comprise\ud
sufficient sensory stimulation to keep us engaged, whilst at the same time providing opportunity for\ud
reflection and relaxation. One essential aspect in safeguarding existing, or developing new `tranquil\ud
space¿, is understanding the optimum relationship between the soundscape and the visual composition\ud
of a location. This research represents a first step in understanding the effects of audio-visual interaction\ud
on the perception of tranquillity and identifies how the interpretation of acoustic information is an\ud
integral part of this process. By using uni and bi-modal auditory-visual stimuli in a two stage experimental\ud
strategy, it has been possible to measure the key components of the tranquillity construct. The\ud
findings of this work should be of particular interest to those charged with landscape management, such\ud
as National Park Authorities, Regional Councils, and other agencies concerned with providing and\ud
maintaining public amenity.EPSRC, Wellcome Trus
